text: This is fascinating! But I wonder how the propulsion system would work using JavaScript?
I think the real question is: why not? JavaScript is everywhere these days, and it's just a matter of time before we get it into outer space.
With enough JavaScript libraries, anything is possible! I can already imagine a future where we npm install rocket-thrusters and blast off.
What about the performance aspect? Wouldn't using JavaScript make the spaceship slower?
I believe the key here is to use WebAssembly. With WebAssembly, you could optimize the performance-critical parts of the spaceship, while still using JavaScript for the less critical aspects.
Absolutely! The combination of JavaScript and WebAssembly could pave the way for a new era of space exploration. I can't wait to see what the future holds.
I'm more concerned about the dependencies. Imagine having to debug your spaceship mid-flight because one of your npm packages has a vulnerability!
Just make sure you don't accidentally install left-pad again, and you should be fine.
Or just use a monorepo for your entire spaceship, and you won't have to worry about dependencies! Problem solved.
I think this is a great opportunity for a new programming paradigm: Space-Oriented Programming. We can design new language features specifically for developing spaceships!
I'm already imagining the possibilities! `const warpDrive = new SpaceTimeWarper({ speed: 'lightspeed' })` Here we come, Alpha Centauri!
I can't wait for the first space coding bootcamp. "Learn to build a spaceship in just 12 weeks!"
